channel.title: NYT > Business Day
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: On the Threshold of Obamacare, Warily
item.description: Some uninsured people are eager to sign up for new state marketplaces, but for others the decision will require a series of complicated calculations.
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
item.dc:creator: By KATIE THOMAS and REED ABELSON
item.media:credit: Angela Shoemaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Without insurance, Lavel White, 26, sometimes doesn’t have a medication refilled.

item.title: When BlackBerry Reigned (the Queen Got One!), and How It Fell
item.description: A short history of the device from a tiny Canadian company that created and, for a long time, dominated what became the smartphone market.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN and JENNIFER DANIEL
item.media:credit: Pool photo by John Stillwell/Getty Images
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth visited Blackberry in 2010, and received one of her own.

item.title: Breaking Up With ‘Breaking Bad’ Is Hard for Albuquerque
item.description: The popular series, which showcased Albuquerque’s grit and high-desert beauty, has helped the city become a star in its own right and given rise to an entire “Breaking Bad” economy.
item.dc:creator: By CLAIRE MARTIN
item.media:description: “Breaking Bad” spawned a small economic boom in Albuquerque. Debbie Ball, in apron, makes a blue candy based on a plotline in the show, and sells it at her store, The Candy Lady.

item.title: Federal Agencies Lay Out Contingency Plans for Possible Shutdown
item.description: Federal agencies have been asked to identify “nonessential” employees, who will be forced to stay home if Congress fails to pass a spending bill.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: The Boss: Back to the Ballet
item.description: The executive director of the New York City Ballet grew up in a musical family — and knew early in life that she wanted to be involved in the arts.
item.dc:creator: By KATHERINE E. BROWN

item.title: Workstation: Modern Offices, Chock-Full of Offenses
item.description: A new book from Judith Martin, known as Miss Manners, and her son is both a sad and hilarious commentary on the state of the modern, open-space workplace.
item.dc:creator: By PHYLLIS KORKKI

item.title: The Chatter for Sunday, September 29
item.description: Notable quotes from business articles that appeared in The New York Times last week.

item.title: Letters: A New Barometer for Executive Pay
item.description: Readers respond to “A Better Way to Compare C.E.O. Pay” (Fair Game, Sept. 22).

item.title: House Leaves U.S. on Brink of Shutdown
item.description: The G.O.P. chose a hard line in their attack on President Obama’s health care law, setting up a vote to attach a delay of the health care law to a bill that would avoid a shutdown.
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
item.dc:creator: By JONATHAN WEISMAN and JEREMY W. PETERS
item.media:description: Representative Eric Cantor walked past the media following a meeting on Saturday with Republicans over the budget in Washington.

item.title: Prototype: Helping Bands Play to the Crowd, Long Before the Show
item.description: For musicians, crowd-sourced fund-raising is lessening the financial risk of performing in new markets.
item.dc:creator: By CLAIRE MARTIN
item.media:credit: Dan Cappellazzo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sean Greenhalgh, left, and Alec Ounsworth of the band Clap Your Hands Say Yeah, which used a service called Rabbl to help it build an audience for a Baltimore show.

item.title: Last Shutdown a Lesson Lost on Capitol Hill
item.description: Even those who lived through past government shutdowns, including in 1995-96, have varied recollections, or none at all, about how and why they happened.
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
item.dc:creator: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER
item.media:description: The budget fight between President Bill Clinton and Newt Gingrich in the mid-1990s paved the way for bipartisan compromises. That is unlikely to be the case today.

item.title: Economic View: Housing Market Is Heating Up, if Not Yet Bubbling
item.description: A home-buyer survey suggests that while the nation isn’t in a housing bubble, there are some troubling signs that it’s heading toward one.
item.category: Standard & Poor's Case-Shiller Home Price Index
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT J. SHILLER

item.title: Corner Office: Jonathan Klein of Getty Images, on Useful Critiques
item.description: The C.E.O. of Getty Images warns against critiquing others’ work in too much detail. “In fiddling over the small stuff,” he says, “you take away all the empowerment.”
item.dc:creator: By ADAM BRYANT
item.media:credit: Yana Paskova for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jonathan Klein, C.E.O. of Getty Images, a distributor and creator of photographs and other media, advises against critiquing others' work in too much detail. "In fiddling over the small stuff," he says, "you take away all the empowerment."

item.title: Datapoints: Why Verizon Wanted It All
item.description: Verizon Communications’ move to buy the remainder of Verizon Wireless reflects the extraordinary profit advantage of wireless over landline service.
item.dc:creator: By ANNA BERNASEK

item.title: Fair Game: Why Judges Are Scowling at Banks
item.description: District court judges are not generally known as flamethrowers, but some seem to be losing patience with banks in cases involving lending practices.
item.category: Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp (Freddie Mac)|FMCC|OTCBB
item.dc:creator: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON

item.title: Strategies: The Bridges Are New, but Business Scams Are Timeless
item.description: A survey suggests that surprising numbers of Americans don’t recognize potentially fraudulent sales pitches — and that the rich are sometimes the most easily fooled.
item.dc:creator: By JEFF SOMMER
item.media:description: Though con artists are no longer selling the Brooklyn Bridge, investors are still susceptible to their schemes.

item.title: Lacking Rules, Insurers Balk at Paying for Intensive Psychiatric Care
item.description: A 2008 law was supposed to make it easier for mental health patients to get treatment, but without clear rules, insurance companies are often reluctant to pay the bill.
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
item.dc:creator: By REED ABELSON
item.media:credit: Christopher Capozziello for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cathy Morelli, right, with her daughter Melissa. Ms. Morelli's insurance company initially refused to pay for Melissa's hospital care.

item.title: N.S.A. Gathers Data on Social Connections of U.S. Citizens
item.description: The analysis of phone call and e-mail logs for foreign intelligence purposes adds to the growing body of knowledge about the agency’s access to private information, prompting concern from lawmakers.
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.dc:creator: By JAMES RISEN and LAURA POITRAS
item.media:description: Gen. Keith Alexander, the director of the National Security Agency, testified on Thursday before the Senate Intelligence Committee.

item.title: Norwegian Air Takes Dreamliner Out of Service After Breakdowns
item.description: Budget airline Norwegian Air Shuttle is taking one of its brand new Dreamliners out of long-haul service and demanding that Boeing repair the plane after it suffered repeated breakdowns, the carrier said on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Today's Economist: A Health Care Fight That Punishes Federal Workers
item.description: Critics of the Affordable Care Act continue to misrepresent its provisions, including one about coverage for Congress and its employees, an economist writes.
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
item.dc:creator: By UWE E. REINHARDT

item.title: Your Money: A Guide to the New Exchanges for Health Insurance
item.description: Details on the Obama administration health care plan are scheduled to be disclosed next week, but it’s never too early to examine the basics.
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
item.dc:creator: By TARA SIEGEL BERNARD

item.title: DealBook: Beats Gets Infusion of Capital From Carlyle Group
item.description: Beats Electronics said that it has secured a minority investment from the Carlyle Group for $500 million, valuing the music company at more than $1 billion.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL J. DE LA MERCED
item.media:description: Beats headphones worn courtside by hip-hop artist Lil Wayne at the 2012 N.B.A. All-Star Game.

item.title: Business Briefing | Legal News: Delaware Judge Rules for Sirius Board in Shareholder Suit
item.description: The board of Sirius XM Radio did not breach its duty to shareholders by allowing a takeover by Liberty Media without demanding a premium for the stock, the judge ruled.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Race to End for ‘Breaking Bad’ Fans Who Got Behind
item.description: Viewers are trying to catch up on old episodes of “Breaking Bad” through Netflix, Amazon, iTunes and other Internet services as the hit series nears its end.
item.dc:creator: By BRIAN STELTER
item.media:description: Walter White, the main character played by Bryan Cranston, is a teacher turned drug lord.

item.title: Exxon to Extend Health Care to Married Same-Sex Couples
item.description: The Exxon Mobil Corporation, which has drawn criticism for policies related to its gay and lesbian workers, said that it would extend health insurance to married same-sex couples effective Oct. 1.
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: By TARA SIEGEL BERNARD
item.media:description: Protesters at the 2008 Exxon annual shareholders meeting in Dallas. Its new policy will cover 77,000 workers and retirees.
